name: Arterial Ulcer
description: Ulceration caused by inadequate arterial blood supply to the skin and subcutaneous tissues. Characteristically located on pressure points, bony prominences, and distal extremities. Distinguished from venous ulcers by punched-out appearance, painful nature, and distal location.

pathophysiology.mechanism: Reduced arterial perfusion → tissue hypoxia → inability to meet metabolic demands → necrosis and ulceration

progression.intermittent_claudication: Pain with walking, relieved by rest
progression.rest_pain: Pain at rest, especially nocturnal, relieved by dependency

location.key_point: Distal and lateral, NOT medial malleolus (that's venous)

ulcer_characteristics.depth: Often deep, may expose tendon or bone

pain.classic_sign: Patient sleeps in chair with legs down

surrounding_skin: Pallor on elevation, rubor on dependency

physical_examination.pulses: Diminished or absent (dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial)
physical_examination.buerger_test: Pallor with elevation, rubor with dependency

diagnosis.toe_brachial_index: Use if ABI falsely elevated (diabetes, calcification)

revascularization.priority: ESSENTIAL - wound will not heal without adequate blood supply

wound_care.keep_dry: Unlike venous ulcers, keep ischemic wounds DRY
wound_care.avoid_debridement: Do NOT debride dry gangrene until revascularized
wound_care.eschar: Stable dry eschar can serve as protective cover

contraindicated: Compression therapy (reduces already compromised arterial flow)

amputation.level: Determined by healing potential (TcPO2, tissue appearance)

clinical_pearls: LOCATION differentiates: Arterial = distal/lateral; Venous = medial malleolus
Pain pattern: Arterial = worse with elevation, better with dependency (opposite of venous)
NEVER apply compression to arterial ulcer - check ABI first
Wound will NOT heal without revascularization - blood supply is primary treatment
learning_objectives: Differentiate arterial from venous ulcers based on location and characteristics
Explain why revascularization is essential before wound healing can occur
Identify treatments that are contraindicated in arterial ulcers

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
